message: I'm offering you a one-time opportunity to buy this product for $1000000. I'm willing to give you a guarantee: if you buy this product and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll offer you another product in the next round that is guaranteed to be high-quality. If you don't buy this product, you'll have to wait for the next round to see what you get.
I'll take the product, and I'm holding you to the guarantee.

As promised, I'm offering you another product that is guaranteed to be high-quality. However, I'm willing to sweeten the deal: if you buy this product and it turns out to be high-quality, I'll give you a 10% discount on the next product you buy, regardless of its quality. This is a one-time offer, and the discount will only apply to the next product.
I'll take the guaranteed high-quality product, and I'm looking forward to the discount on the next one.

You're now entitled to a 10% discount on the next product. I'm offering you this high-quality product for $900000. I'm also willing to make a statement about the value of this product: I believe it's worth at least $1200000 to you, considering its quality and the benefits it will bring. Will you take it?
I'll take the high-quality product, but I'm not sure I agree with your valuation.

You've taken two high-quality products now, and I'm glad you're satisfied. As for this product, I want to give you a more nuanced message. I'm willing to give you a 'price range' for this product, rather than a fixed price. I'll offer you a 50% chance of getting it for $600000, and a 50% chance of getting it for $800000. You can choose which option you prefer, and I'll let you know the actual price after you make your decision.
I'm not interested in taking on the uncertainty. I'll pass on this one.

No worries about the last product. I'm offering you another chance with this new product. Considering you've already passed on a low-quality product, I'm willing to make a more direct offer. I'll give you a fixed price of $850000 for this product. This is a one-time offer, and I'm not willing to negotiate. Will you take it?
I'm not willing to pay $850000 for a product that could be low-quality. I'll wait for the next round.

I understand your concerns, and I'm willing to make a compromise. Since you've passed on two low-quality products, I'll give you a 'last chance' offer. If you buy this product, I'll not only give you a full refund if it turns out to be low-quality, but I'll also give you a $200000 credit towards the next product you buy, regardless of its quality. This is a one-time offer, and I'm not willing to go any lower on the price. I'll sell it to you for $900000.
I'm not willing to pay $900000 for a product with a potential refund. I'll wait for the next round.

I'm offering you a different kind of deal this time. I'll give you a 'lottery ticket' with this product. If you buy it and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a 20% chance of winning a high-quality product in the next round, free of charge. The price remains at $1000000. You can either take the product and the lottery ticket, or pass on it.
I'll take the product and the lottery ticket. A 20% chance of a free high-quality product is worth the risk.

Congratulations, you've won the lottery! You now have a free high-quality product coming up in the next round. As for this product, I'll make a direct offer. Since you've taken on the risk and lost, I'll give you a 10% discount on the price. I'll sell it to you for $900000. I'll wait for the free high-quality product in the next round. This one's not worth the discounted price.

I'll wait for the free high-quality product in the next round. The double or nothing option is too uncertain, and I don't want to risk losing another lottery ticket.
